Aurora has dedicated herself to selling cosmetics and perfumes. She sells a line of perfumes manufactured in Guayaquil called Yanbal. When Aurora’s husband had a hard time finding a job, she quit her job as full time mom and opened her shop, Cosméticos Esmeralda, in order to support the family.

She is asking for this, her second loan, in order to increase the selection of perfumes for her customers. She took out her previous loan in December, which proved profitable because cologne and perfume are popular things to save up for and give as gifts.

Although her relationship with her husband is shaky, they individually work hard to provide for their children. Her wish is to be able to earn enough money from operating Cosmeticos Esmeralda so that she can cover the costs of living for herself and the remaining kids who still live in the home.

loans.use: Continue investing in cosmetics and perfumes

loans.name: Rosula

texts.es:
Rosula M. is 42 years old and married to Melanio Esquivel. They have 5 children, two who are older and three still in school.

Rosula started her business with savings from the money her husband earned as an employee of a public transportation company. In 2000, she rented a small space right in the terminal where her husband worked, where every day there was an interesting movement of people traveling, and so she saw a brilliant opportunity for this type of business. She started selling fast food such as empanadas, vegetable tarts, fried meats and snacks, and after she diversified her products with more elaborately prepared food.

Today this business is very viable, because she has an established customer base and also offers a catering service for many who can't go home to eat. The loan will be used to buy various merchandise. In addition to the her business serving meals, she also has a small dispensary.

La señora Rosula M. tiene 42 años de edad, está casada con el señor Melanio Esquivel, matrimonio con cinco hijos, dos mayores de edad y tres en edad escolar. Rosula comenzó su negocio con los ahorros que genero con el dinero que ganaba su marido quien trabaja como empleado en una empresa de transporte público de pasajeros, en el año 2000, alquiló un pequeño salón justamente en la terminal de la empresa donde trabajaba su marido, en donde cada día había un movimiento interesante de personas que viajaban, por lo tanto vio una oportunidad brillante para este tipo de negocio. Comenzó vendiendo comidas rápidas tales como: empanadas, milanesas, croquetas, tartas de verduras, etc. y luego fue diversificando sus productos ya con comidas mas elaboradas. Hoy en día dicha actividad le es muy rentable, porque ya tiene una clientela formada e incluso ya ofrece servicio de catering para muchos que no pueden ir a comer a sus casas. El crédito será utilizado para la compra de mercaderías varias, ya que además de la venta de comidas posee una pequeña despensa.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, noodles, meat, etc.

loans.name: Issa

texts.en: Issa H. is a 42-year-old father of three. He lives in the Kisiwani area. He has been in the business of collecting scrap metal for the past four years. He sells the scrap metal to small manufacturers of various machines. He uses some of the metal himself, to manufacture charcoal stoves. He is asking for $375 to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his scrap metal business

loans.name: Ravshan

texts.en: Ravshan R. lives in Mastchoh; he is married and has 5 children. He has been a client of MicroInvest since 2005. He is a serious and strongly motivated borrower. He is eligible for an increased loan amount because of the stability of his business and its increasing profits. He breeds and sells livestock and operates a dairy. He would like to purchase a pedigreed bull for breeding purposes and a cow for the dairy.  He plans to expand the assortment of products he sells: pasteurized milk, buttermilk, sour cream, cottage cheese, and so on. He is asking for a loan of $725 to buy this livestock, which will allow him to expand his product line and increase the family's income.

loans.use: To buy a bull and a dairy cow

loans.name: Ann Osaghae

texts.en: Ann is a woman of 54 years old is married with five children. She sells akara (bean cake). She is from Edo state and also a LAPO member. She needs the loan amount of $200 to enable her buy more bags of beans and gallons of oil for her trade. She learned business for 4 months and started it in 2002.

loans.use: To buy more bags of beans and gallons of oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Working his land for his rice crop/harvest.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is 52 years old. He lives in Nabatieh in southern Lebanon and is married with one child. Ali sells mobile phones.

This is the first time Ali has applied for a loan at Al Majmoua. He wants to buy mobile phones and accessories to sustain and develop his business.

loans.use: To buy mobile phones and accessories.

loans.name: Clara

texts.es:
Mrs Clara is a member of Las Azucenas 2 Community Bank, located at Av. Bellavista Cdra. 9, Calleria District, Ucayali State. She is 47 years old and has three grown-up children. Using the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos (Kiva Field Partner) for approximately $110, she opened a small barbershop. At present, she has a beauty salon, which she runs with the help of her children. She works as a hairdresser herself from 8 am to 6.00 pm. With this loan, which will be repaid in 4 months, she plans to purchase various salon products such as haircolor, shampoos, hairsprays, combs, scissors, etc.

Clara is very glad as she feels she is very much supported by Manuela Ramos, and that her salon attracts more customers everyday and her business profit is increasing steadily.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Clara pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas 2, ubicado en el Av. Bellavista Cdra. 9, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 años y es madre de 3 hijos mayores de edad. Clara con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en una pequeña peluquería. En la actualidad tiene un salón de belleza, que atiende con la ayuda de sus hijos, ella atiende su peluqueria desede las 8 am. Hasta las 6.00 pm. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500 el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará materiales para ondulación, tintes, champús, lacas, peines, tijeras, capas, etc. Clara esta feliz por que se siente muy apoyada por Manuela Ramos, y su negocio tiene cada día mas clientes y sus ganancias se esta incrementando.

loans.use: Purchase of various products for the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: As additional capital to buy more raw materials for production of a local drink

loans.name: Felorita Lifa's Group

texts.en: These three members from SPBD's Gautavai Center are asking for their first loan of 2250 Tala, which is the maximum of 750 Tala each. They are hard-working ladies whose work includes a taro plantation, a business that earns 200 Tala a week, with a profit of 90 Tala after expenses including the loan repayment. They also have a sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for their farming and sewing businesses

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel is 46 years old, a mother of 4 children, one already being an independent, the other 3 are single and work. For some time she has dedicated herself to the sale of sweets, her partner, Mr. Ulises supports her in all of her aspirations, he is a bricklayer. Isabel does not only dedicate herself to these products, but also, she sells desserts in the afternoons, she does all of this to help with family expenses. Mrs. Isabel wants to increase her sales of sweets and build in the back of her store, she has many ideas for the business, and she needs capital to help raise her desires to succeed and grow. Help this mother that with effort and eagerness continues working hard, she will not disappoint you.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Isabel tiene 46 años, es madre de 4 hijos, siendo uno de ellos ya independiente, los otros 3 solteros y trabajan a parte. Ella desde hace mucho tiempo se dedica a la venta de golosinas, su pareja, el señor Ulises la apoya en todas sus aspiraciones, él es albañil. Isabel no sólo se dedica a la venta de estos productos, sino también, vende por las tardes picarones (postres), todo esto lo hace por ayudar con los gastos familiares. La señora Isabel quiere incrementar su venta de golosinas y construir posteriormente su bodega, ella tiene muchas ideas de negocio, y para eso necesariamente estima de un capital que levantará sus ganas de seguir adelante y crecer. Apoyemos a esta madre que con esfuerzo y ahínco sigue dándole duro al trabajo, ella no te defraudará.

loans.use: To carry out her business with better merchandise.

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony E. is a commercial driver who uses his own car. At the moment the car is giving him problems and he needs financial assistance to buy spare parts for the repairs of his car. He is married, but his wife's income as a farmer is not sufficient for them and their 6 children. Demand for his services is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits.

He is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand his business.

loans.name: Monica

texts.es:
Mónica inició el negocio porque falleció su esposo y se quedo desamparada con tres hijos y necesitaba solventar los gastos del hogar, así como pagarles la escuela y las deudas que le dejo la enfermedad de su esposo y el pago de su casa. Ella se dedicó a la venta de ropa nueva y usada y le ha ido bien hasta la fecha.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $675 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancía nueva y seminueva para el desarrollo del negocio y tener más ventas.
texts.en:
Mónica started a business when she lost her husband and was left with three children and the dilemma of how to pay for houshold expenses. These expenses include her children's schooling costs and the debts resulting from her husband's illness as well as house payments. She began selling new and used clothes and the business has been going well up until now.

Mónica needs a loan of $675 to purchase new and almost-new merchandise for the development of her business and to increase sales; she will repay the loan within six months.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Mr. Kreus Moeun's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan will be shared by twelve people who live in Preak Reusei Village in Kandal Province, Cambodia. Each members of the loan group plans to use the loan for a different purpose. 

Mr. Eng M. has been selected by the members to be the village bank president. He and his wife, Mrs. San K., are farmers. They face a small problem because their field is infertile. To solve this problem, Mr. Eng M. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field and to make his crop more productive. He is 54 years old and the father of two children who attend the local school. 

Mr. Kreus C. did not come to the loan meeting, but his wife attended, so she appears in the photograph.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly-payment loans. Members with end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to support his field and make his crop more productive.

loans.name: Aina

texts.en:
Aina sells snacks, drinks and juice. Customers also hire her to bake cakes for their social engagements like birthday parties, marriages, etc. She has been in this business for the past eight years.

Aina is 36 years old and married to I. who works in a block factory. They have four children and they are all attending school. Aina and her husband are determined to give their children a quality education. Aina needs the loan to purchase more drinks, juice, and baking materials like flour, sugar, etc to sell. She says thank you to all who have made this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more baking materials, juice and drinks to sell

loans.name: Maria Elisa

texts.es:
Maria Elisa inició el negocio porque le gustan las ventas y así no descuida su casa porque trabajo solamente el tiempo necesario.
empezó vendiendo ropa porque una vecina le paso una paca de ropa a un muy buen precio, y decidió sacarle provecho vendiendo esa ropa afuera de su casa, obteniendo ganancias para pagarle lo de la paca y para invertir en mas material para que no dejar de surtir su negocio.

Ahora necesita un préstamo por MXN $4,000 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar una paca de ropa y poder continuar con su negocio.
texts.en:
Maria Elisa started her business because she likes sales and she does not have to neglect her household because she only works the necessary hours. She started selling clothing because a neighbor gave her a packet of clothing for a very good price. She decided to take advantage by selling that clothing from her home, earning enough profit to pay for the clothing and to invest in more material so that her business would still have a supply.

Now she needs a loan for $325 that she will repay in 3 months. She will use it to buy another packet of clothing to keep her business going.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly Wester, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a packet of clothing

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha V., a 47-year-old widow, lives in Svay Ta Thorm village in Kampong Cham province. She is a grocer who owns a small store in the market, and she wants to expand her grocery, as she now has a large customer base. She decided to request a loan so that she might purchase more grocery goods and expand her inventory. Mrs. Sokha V. has a child who is employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To expand the inventory of her grocery store

loans.name: Souleman

texts.fr: Souleman A. est un jeune homme de 35 ans, marié et père d’un petit garçon. Il est vendeur de brochettes devant un bar dans un quartier populaire de Lomé, la capitale du Togo. Ses plats sont appréciés par la clientèle. Pour donner d’élan à son activité, il désire avec ce crédit acheter des boucs pour l’abattage afin de mieux servir la clientèle. Ceci lui permettra d’augmenter ses recettes et par là épargner plus pour mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Souleman A. is a young man, 35 years of age, married, and the father of a young boy. He sells brochettes in front of a bar in the working-class district of Lomé, the capital of Togo. His customers appreciate the food he offers. To bring momentum to his business, he would like to use this loan to buy goats to slaughter in order to serve his customers better. This will enable him to increase his receipts and thus to earn more, so that his can provide for his family more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy goats for slaughter

loans.name: Mr. Jok Jor Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eighteen people who all live in Trapang Kda village in Kampong Chhnang province make up the village bank loan. Mr. Jok J. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. He owns a coal kiln where he can make coal to sell for an income. Since this business is going well, he wants to sell his coal door-to-door, so he decided to ask for a loan to buy a cart in order to carry his coal to sell. His wife, Mrs. Tes Saran, is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Mr. Jok J. is 32 years old and the father of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other two are attending the local school.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Fifteen members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These clients are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a cart in order to carry coal for door-to-door sales.

loans.name: Fiaola

texts.en: Fiaola S., 40, is married with 5 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the BBQ  business. She sells to the General Public, 6 days per week. She has made 2 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~200 USD).  SPBD loans are Fiaola’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy ingredients needed to run her BBQ business and material for home improvement

loans.use: Purchase two boxes of drumsticks, a cooking stove, pots, a cooler and roofing materials

loans.name: Chey

texts.en: Chey Y. was born in 1979 and is married with four single children who are employed as garment workers.  Her husband works in construction to help cover the family’s expenses. He earns $3 per day.  Chey sells Khmer fritters in her village, and has also cultivated rice for years. With the mature rice season approaching, Chey is hoping to buy a rice cultivating machine which she will rent to other farmers. She is requesting a loan of $500 for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy a cultivating machine

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam has been a clothes (dress made materials) seller in the Darajabovu neighborhood of Zanzibar for 6 years. She belongs to the Umoja ni nguvu loan group (group code 2011). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $95. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes (dress made materials) for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Mariam is 41 years old, married, and has five children.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to expand her business.

loans.name: Onyinyechi

texts.en: Onyinyechi is 27 years old and married with two children. She sells frozen foods like turkey, chicken, etc. She hopes for the loan of N50,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She promises to pay back her loan promptly. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Sayora

texts.ru: Искандарова Сайера- молодая девушка ей 21 лет. Занимается вязанием шерстянных носков и переработкой пряжи. Сайере помогает мама и старшая сестра. Свой товар она продает на рынках Ошоба и Аппон Аштского района. Она узнала о нашей организации у своих соседей и решила придти в наш офис. Ей понравились все наши условия теперь она наша клиентка. На полученный займ она хочет оптом купит пряжу. Отец Муниры находится на заработках в Казахстане, поэтому она с мамой вынуждены сами работать.
texts.en:
Sayora I. is young, 21-year-old woman. She is involved in knitting of wool socks and processing of yarn. Her mother and sister assist her with the business. Sayora sells her products at the Oshoba and Appon markets in the Asht district. She found out about our organization from her neighbors and decided to come to our office. She liked all of our terms and became our client. Sayora wants to use this loan to purchase yarn wholesale. Sayora’s father is working in Kazakhstan, which is why Sayora and her mother need to work.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of yarn

loans.name: Hoàng Thị

texts.en:
H. Hoàng Thị (1014081764) is a 35 year-old female living in the town of Nghi Lộc.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, H. owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising chickens for sale.  H. has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 2500000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2001, H. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  H. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000000 VND from TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.  H. is now requesting a new loan of 10000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  The loan will be the 8th loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund.  H. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand the borrower's business.

loans.use: used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: María Azucena

texts.es: María Azucena J. de 52 años de edad vive junto a su hijo, nieta, nuera y una hermana en Tonacatepeque. Ella tiene 8 años de poseer un salón de bella en el cual comercializa también cosméticos y ropa. Ella solicita un préstamo con el fin de poder comprar más cosméticos, y poder comprar ropa al mayoreo y comprar sombrillas para esta época de lluvia. María desea mucho poder mejorara las ganancias de su negocio, ya que a pesar de la situación económica que ha vivido ha logrado sobrevivir gracias a su negocio.
texts.en:
Maria Azucena Jimenez is 52 years old and lives with her son, her granddaughter, daughter-in-law and a sister in Tonacatepeque. She has owned a beauty salon for 8 years, in which she also sells cosmetics and clothing. She is requesting a loan in order to be able to purchase more cosmetics and clothing at wholesale, and also buy umbrellas for this rainy season. Maria wishes very much to improve the income from her business, since in spite of the financial conditions that she lived through she has been able to survive thanks to this business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing, cosmetics and umbrellas.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is married and mother of three children. All her children are in school in the community where she lives. She trades in baking materials like flour, vegetables oil, sugar etc. She has rented a store in which she trades her goods. Through her customer care and dedication she has attracted lots of customers who buy from her instead of going to town. She takes delivery of goods from Kumasi in bulk and sells them at retail. She requests the loan to buy margarine, flour, sugar, etc. in bulk. She wants to use the profit to provide for the education of her children.

loans.use: To buy food staples in bulk for resale

loans.name: Graciela Del Carmen

texts.es: Graciela del Carmen M. López tiene 40 años. Su actividad económica es venta de cosmeticos. Hace más de 4 años que se dedica a esta humilde actividad. Tiene 2 hijos a su cargo. Además Graciela labora en un instituto como directora en su comunidad. Por lo que todos los días tiene que encargarse de realizar sus labores. Para que su familia pueda tener lo necesario para alimentarse. Ya que en sus desafíos se encuentra su hija, por lo que muchas veces tiene asistir al hospital para que la asistan ella tiene la enfermedad de asma y sufre al ver a su hija tan enferma. El destino del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de colonia, cremas, pinturas de uñas entre otros. Su mayor sueño es lograr que sus hijos sean buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
Graciela del Carmen M. López is 40 years old and has 2 children. She has been selling cosmetics for over 4 years. Graciela also works as a director at a community institute, where she is in charge of the employees. Her family has only what is necessary to feed themselves. They face many challenges because her daughter is asthmatic and has had to visit the hospital on several occasions. It is difficult for Sra. Graciela to see her daughter so sick.

Her loan will be used as operating capital to purchase colognes, creams, nail polish and other products. Her biggest dream is that her children become successful professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa A. is married and has two children. She has received schooling through senior high school. Theresa sells soap and salt at Elmina, which she has been doing since 2008. Her husband works with the forestry department. Theresa uses her income to support in the up keep of the house. Theresa will use the loan to purchase soap and salt in large quantities to resell at the market. With the new profits from her expanded business, Theresa plans to educate her dependants.

loans.use: Theresa will use the loan to purchase soap and salt in large quantities to resell at the market.

loans.name: Fredy Cesar

texts.en:
Fredy is a member of the Valley Roses village bank. He is single, 24 years-old, and has a 3-year-old daughter who lives with her mom and goes to kindergarten. 
Fredy and his parents came from Junín to Lima after he finished his studies in school. He started studying English in the evenings but had to stop because he could not afford to keep spending the money. 
He started to work in a textile business near his house but stopped because they moved to another district and he was spending a lot on transportation. He saw an opportunity to work in San Juan as a taxi driver. He contacted the taxi company and was able to rent a taxi.
Since he has joined FINCA he has had the opportunity to increase his income. Fredy needs a loan of 1200 soles to make the initial payment on his taxi. His dream is to someday own his own taxi.

loans.use: Make the initial payment on his taxi

loans.name: Mutua

texts.en:
Mutua N. is a 27 year old married father of one child called Fundi Nicholas who is seven months. His wife Esther Mawia is 25 years old and the family lives in Mshomori in Mombasa.

Mutua is in the business of selling second hand shoes in the busy Kongowea market and has been in operation for five years. 

He has never accessed any loan from a lending organization and with this first borrowing from KADET he plans to purchase second hand bails of clothes in an effort to diversify his shoe selling business.

He hopes to open a bigger store in future in order to maximize on his income.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Purchasing second hand clothes bails.

loans.name: Somadje Koko Mimi

texts.fr: Cette femme est gérante d’un débit de boissons dans le quartier de Baguida à Lomé ; elle a débuté cette activité depuis 2006 et cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans la vie du foyer. Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle vend aussi bien en gros qu’en détail ; elle reçoit des commandes de la part de ses clients lors des fêtes, mariages et anniversaires et est bien connue des gens du quartier. Elle pense dans un proche avenir se lancer aussi dans le commerce d’alimentation générale dans sa boutique. C’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour s’approvisionner en produits d’alimentation générale ; le prêt servira aussi à commander 40 casiers de boissons de toutes sortes.
texts.en:
This woman manages a drinks depot in the neighborhood of Baguida in Lomé; she began this business in 2006 and this business enables her to contribute financially to the needs of her family. She is married and the mother of one child. She sells at wholesale, as well as retail. She receives orders from her clients for parties marriages and anniversaries. She is well-known in the neighborhood. In the future she intends to turn her business into a general grocery store. It is for this reason that she is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to acquire these general food products. This loan will also be used to order 40 cases of drinks of all sorts.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cases of drinks

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Martina sells goods in the village of Marcos, Roxas, Isabela. She is married to Ricardo; they were blessed with three children, all of whom are married. Her income from her store really helps meet the needs of her grandchildren. She wants her business to make more of a profit so that she can continue to help her grandchildren.

Consequently, she wants to borrow PHP 10,000. It would serve as additional capital for her "sari-sari" (variety) store. Martina plans to buy additional goods for her store with the money. She is also planning to buy vegetables that she can sell in their village and thus have an additional source of income.

loans.use: purchasing more goods for her store and starting a new business

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 34 years old and married with two daughters, aged 9 and 3. He runs a boda boda (motorbike) taxi business in Kitengela, a small town near Nairobi. He has operated his business for two years and has three employees. He supplements his income with a milk-supply business and previously sold cereals. He is requesting a loan for 40,000 Kenyan shillings to add another motorbike to the business. 

Peter describes himself as optimistic, hardworking and self-driven and hopes to expand his business with more motorbikes and a trailer for transport.

loans.use: Buy another motorbike

loans.name: Chinbat

texts.en:
J. Chinbat is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Harhorin, the capital city of the ancient Mongolian empire. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son and two daughters attend a local secondary school.

Chinbat operates a raw material trading business in his town. He sells animal skins, primarily sheep and goat skins. He started his business in 1999 after previously working as a driver for a state-owned farm. Over the years, Chinbat has become quite experienced in raw materials trading and has built a stable operation. He is now planning to expand his business in the near future. Chinbat's business is very important to him and his family. He says, "All I want is to provide for my children's education and raise them to be good people." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase sheep and goat skins to sell for his business.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and goat skins

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional goods for her shop business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria, de 54 años, es una mujer que a lo largo de la vida a trabajado mucho por sobresalir en la vida, vive en su casa propia y lo que más desea es tener un futuro tranquilo.
Su puesto de venta de ropa está ubicado en el mercado San José (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), ella vende específicamente polos para jóvenes y es muy buena vendedora, puesto que siempre convence a sus clientes de comprarle más de un prenda de vestir.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinas de venta, lleva 33 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día en su puesto de venta sin poder salir a la calle.
Para más adelante, espera poder juntar el dinero necesario para tener una tienda de ropa.

Este es el quinto préstamo de Maria con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagarlo a tiempo para no meter en problemas a las socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy querida. Con los tres mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más polos, ya que desea implementar mejor su puesto de ventas.
texts.en:
Maria, age 54, is a woman who has worked hard throughout her life to get ahead. She lives in her own house, and her greatest desire is to have a tranquil future. The stand where she sells clothes is located in the San José market (an important market in the city of Juliaca). Specifically, she sells polo shirts for young people, and she is an excellent salesperson, since she always convinces her customers to buy more than one garment. What she likes most about her work is conversing with the salespeople from neighboring stands. She has been in this line of work for 33 years, and she thinks the most difficult part is having to spend the entire day at her sales stand without being able to go out onto the street. For the future, she hopes to be able to save enough money to open her own clothing store. This is Maria's fifth loan with MFP; she knows that she needs to pay it on time to avoid causing problems for the other members of her communal bank, where she is well-liked. With the 3000 Peruvian nuevos soles she is requesting, she will purchase more polo shirts, since she wants to increase the sales volume of her stand.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing additional merchandise

loans.name: Mercedes' Group

texts.en:
Mercedes S. is from the village of Olango. She is 52 years old. Mercedes is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI, one of Kiva's field partners. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Mercedes is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Mercedes raises pigs to sell. Mercedes has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $110 a month from this activity.

In 2007, Mercedes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Mercedes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Mercedes is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 6th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Luzvilla

texts.en:
Luzvilla B., 53 years old, started to manage a rice farm in 1979. Now she is still pursuing this business because it helps her family a lot in buying the daily needs in their home.

Luzvilla is asking for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and farm supplies.

Luzvilla chooses CEVI because aside from loans, she receives insurance coverage from CEVI as well.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Viola Balingway's Group

texts.en:
Viola B. is 47 years old and from the town of Dappig, San Agustin. She is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Viola is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling home products. The main source of income for the business comes from selling home products to tourists and local community members. Viola has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2010, Viola joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generaT. to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posT. using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva creaT. this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Flordeliza's Group

texts.en:
Flordeliza D. is from the village of Brgy. Tuao North, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 50 years old. Flordeliza is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Flordeliza is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Flordeliza owns & operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Flordeliza is just starting this business.

In 2010, Flordeliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flordeliza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Flordeliza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es: La Sra. Elvira tiene una tienda ubicada en la zona D. Munaypata D. nuestra ciudad, su domicilio esta ubicado a dos cuadras en la misma calle, su negocio tiene una gran variedad D. productos a pesar D. que el espacio que ocupa es pequeño, la Sra. Elvira esta casada y tiene 3 hijas D. 22,15 y 12 años D. edad, ellas están estudiando, una en la universidad y las otras dos estan en colegio. Su esposo es cerrajero y trabaja en la zona D. Obrajes D. nuestra ciudad ellos según cuentan empezaron D. cero y trabajando consiguieron comprar su casita y ahora están en una situacion economica aceptable, ellos están muy orgullosos D. su trabajo y siempre muestran responsabilidad en sus pagos, son una familia muy unida, el deseo D. la Sra. Elvira es ver a sus hijas profesionales, con el dinero del credito comprara mercaderia para surtir su tienda, esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Elvira has a store located in the Munaypata zone of our city. Her home is located two blocks away, on the same street. She carries a large variety of products, despite the fact that the space she occupies is small. Elvira is married and has 3 daughters, ages 22, 15, and 12. They are all studying, one in the university and the other two in school. Her husband is a locksmith and works in the Obrajes zone of the city. They tell us they started with nothing and, through hard work, managed to buy a little house and put themselves in an acceptable financial situation. They are very proud of their work, and always demonstrate responsibility with their loan payments. They are a very tight-knit family. Elvira’s wish is to see her daughters all become professionals. She will use the money from the loan to buy merchandise to supply her store. She is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence they’ve shown in her by granting credit.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of various products.

loans.name: Juana Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora Juana del Socorro H. H., trabaja para la escuela Marcos Dessys de la ciudad de Chinandega, se desempeña como maestra de primaria es casada tiene un hijo de tan solo 1 añito, habita en el barrio Roberto González.

La señora Juana solicito el crédito para reparar su vivienda ya que la tiene a media y necesita a asegurarla por que la mayor parte del tiempo pasa sola y se le pueden meter a robar sus pertenencias.
texts.en:
Juana del Socorro H. H. is a primary school teacher at Marcos Dessys School in Chinandega. She is married, lives in the Roberto González neighborhood, and has a one-year-old son. Juana is requesting a loan to make repairs to her home, since it is not currently secure and robbers could enter to steal her belongings.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cement, bricks, and zinc tiles

loans.name: Hasanatu

texts.en: Hasanatu S. is 40 years old,married with two children, both girls. One is in primary school and the last is in nursery school. Hasanatu lives in Ogoo Farm with her family, where she has a  provision shop.She has taken two previous loans from LAPO,SL, with which she purchased more provisions into her shop.She is asking for a loan of 1,000,000 Leones to enable her grow in business.

loans.use: This loan will be used to buy food and drinks for sale.

loans.name: Jacqueline Del Socorro

texts.es:
Doña Jacqueline es madre de familia de tres hijos, tiene 45 años de edad, y trabaja en costura desde hace varios años, a si como la preparación y venta de nacatamales, cereales con el propósito de poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos ya que la canasta básica ah incrementado, la ropa, utensilios escolares. Su esposo trabaja en mecánica, soldador  ala vez, con su apoyo logro la inversión de venta de comida y su cliente en costura la logro mediante a sus esfuerzos. Con este préstamo lograra comprar telas variadas, alimentos para hacer nacatamales y así equilibrar sus ventas.
Mediante los financiamientos se ha beneficiado para mantener su negocio y lograr la captación de nuevos clientes.
texts.en:
Jacqueline is the mother of three children. She is 45 years old and has worked as a seamstress for many years. She has also prepared and sold Nicaraguan tamales and sold cereals to help her husband with expenses, now that their basic needs and their need for clothing and school materials have increased. Her husband is a mechanic and welder. With his encouragement, she was able to invest her food and seamstress work sales into her business efforts. With this loan, she will be able to buy different cloth and ingredients to make Nicaraguan tamales, and to even out her sales. This financing has benefitted her in maintaining her business and has allowed her to serve new clients.

Translated from Spanish by Flavia Garcia, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various cloths, also ingredients to make tamales and to increase sales.

loans.name: Florentino

texts.es:
EL SR. FLORENTINO  HIJO DE DON CARMELO  Y DE DOÑA BALERIANA. NACIO EL 26 DE ABRIL DE 1990 EN VILLA TUMAVI A 25 KM DE LIMONCITO, TIENE SU PARCELA Y TRABAJA CON SU ESPOSA MODESTA TIENES 4 HIJOS QUE SE ENCUENTRAN EN EDAD ESCOLAR Y CUANDO NO VAN A LA ESCUELA LO AYUDAN EN LA SIEMBRA Y COSECHA DE SUS PRODUCTOS, SIEMBRAN MAIZ, PAPA, POROTO, CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARAN SEMILLAS PARA LA SIEMBRA DE PAPA YA QUE ES TEMPORADA DE SIEMBRA 
UNA VES COSECHADO LO COMERCIALIZAN EN EL MERCADO DE LA ZONA, ESTAN MUY AGRADECIDOS CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACAION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Mr. Florentino, son of Mr. Carmelo and Mrs Balieriana, was born on April 26, 1990, in Villa Tumavia, 25 kilometers from Limonicito. He has a piece of land and works with his wife, Modesta. They have 4 school-aged children, and when they aren’t in school, they help in the planting and harvesting of the crops. They sow corn, potatoes, and green beans. With the money from the loan they will buy seeds for planting potatoes since it is now the season. Once harvested they will sell it in the market of their area. They are very thankful for Emprender and Kiva with the confidence shown them by the issuing of the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds

loans.name: Lucia Isac

texts.pt:
Lucia Isac N. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, vive maritalmente é mãe de 3 filhos com idades compriendidas entre os 19 aos 25 anos. Duas mais velhas estão empregadas na educação somente o mais novo é que vai a escola. Vive na casa própria com sua familia e não responsabiliza se por niguem.  

Lúcia quando frequentava a 6ª classe fica grávida e interrompe os estudos, Após o parto Lúcia contínua a viver em casa dos progenitores estes que cuidaram dela nos momentos mais difíceis da sua vida. Anos depois ela retoma os seus estudos e consegue fazer a 10ª classe, de seguida faz o curso de professorado no Distrito de Namaacha na fronteira da Suazilândia. 

Abandonou o curso depois de se juntar com seu actual esposo, o mesmo que lhe deu um valor para iniciar com seu próprio negócio de venda de potes adquiridas em Maputo e revendidas na Suazilândia, actividade que pratica ate então, nas quartas e sábados no mercado informal a céu aberto. Nesta actividade consegue um rendimento de cerca de 6.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa ainda consegue poupar algum com ajuda da sua machamba de hortícolas (alface e couve) que possui no quintal da sua casa.

Este é o sétimo empréstimo de Lúcia na Hluvuku e segundo com Kiva. Os seis primeiros de (5.000.00mt, 5.000.00mt, 12.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt e 10.000.00mt) foram usados para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria, valores que pagou sem nenhum problema e solicita este de 12.000.00mt para o mesmo fim. Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo determinado e pedir um novo empréstimo para concluir a sua obra.
texts.en:
Lúcia Isac N. was born in the city of Maputo. She is married and has three children between the ages of 19 and 25. The two eldest have jobs in education, and only the youngest still goes to school. Lúcia lives in her own house with her family and does not support anyone else. Lúcia became pregnant in sixth grade and quit school. After the birth of her child, Lúcia continued to live in her parents' house, and they took care of her during the most difficult time of her life. Some years later, she returned to school and finished tenth grade. After that, she immediately took a teaching course in Namaacha District, which is on the border with Swaziland. She quit the class when she got together with her current husband, who gave her the money to start her own business selling pots which she buys in Maputo and resells in Swaziland. She still does this work on Wednesdays and Saturdays at the open-air market. Lúcia earns about 6,000 meticais per month, which she uses for household expenses. She also manages to save some money with the help of the vegetable garden in her yard, where she grows lettuce and cabbage. This is Lúcia's seventh loan with Hluvuku and her second with Kiva. The first six loans were for 5,000 meticais, 5,000 meticais, 12,000 meticais, 10,000 meticais, 10,000 meticais and 10,000 meticais. They were used to increase her inventory, and she paid them back with no problems. She is now asking for 12,000 meticais for the same purpose. Lúcia is confident that she will pay off this loan ahead of schedule and ask for another loan for a construction project.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pots, casserole dishes, etc.

loans.name: Vasilina

texts.en:
Vasilina is divorced with two daughters and a son. She is an entrepreneur from Uzhgorod who sells souvenirs, gifts and items made out of fur, like hats, warm vests and even footwear. Vasilina has been in this business for seven years. She has learned how to reach potential customers and make good deals with them. Many clients who have bought from her keep coming back for other reasonably-priced items.  Vasilina’s net profit amounts to about 9,500 Grivnyas a month. 

Vasilina is requesting a loan of 18,300 Grivnyas to diversify the assorted merchandise she offers for sale in her gift kiosk. Vasilina calculates all her costs. She has always been a financially conscious entrepreneur, which has helped her business develop and stay competitive in this region of Ukraine. Being a single mom, Vasilina works hard to make sure her children have all their needs met. One of her biggest goals is to see all three of them in college some day.

loans.use: To diversify her assorted merchandise

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle A. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 21 years old. Michelle is married and has a 5-year-old child. To make a living, Michelle owns & operates a fishing business, operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. Michelle has been engaged in her business for over 10 years.

Michelle joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Michelle has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Michelle is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Michelle from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Prosperity. Group

texts.en:
Delkontee M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Prosperity. In the photo she is holding the sign, She is 42 years old, married and has two children who range from 9 to 15 years old.  Delkontee was only able to attend school through the 12th grade due to lack of financial support.  For 16 years, she has been selling coconuts in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 12,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 60,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more coconuts. She describes herself as easy-going. Her dream is to expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more coconuts to sell

loans.name: Aaron

texts.en:
Aaron, owner of Aaron’s Barrels and Containers, successfully built a business around a versatile product: a large, heavy-duty plastic barrel. As his marketing materials explain, the barrels have a wide variety of uses: from rain-water catchment systems to BBQ marinating to bear-proof camping storage. 
 
“I’m selling something that you can’t find at Home Depot or Wal-Mart,” says Aaron. “I’ve found my niche!” 
 
Aaron’s clients are predominantly eco-friendly organizations, companies, and individuals who are setting up systems to re-use grey water, create their own solar water heaters, or build compost tumblers. A local orchid society, for example, found that their plants responded better to harvested rain water than to tap water, which has been treated with chlorine. Local wineries big and small have also come to Aaron for barrels to store their harvested grapes. 
 
Since starting his business four years ago, Aaron has seen demand for his barrels rise steadily. While Aaron admits that running a business comes with its own set of challenges, the ability to determine his own schedule is indispensable because he has spent the last fifteen years helping to care for sick and elderly family members. 
 
A $4,000 loan, his third from Opportunity Fund, will help Aaron secure a new location for his operations, as well as increase his inventory of supplies. As the autumn harvest and winter rainy season approach, his busiest times of the year, Aaron is excited to get the business running at full capacity in a new space. 

If you’d like to find out more about the products sold by Aaron’s Barrels and Containers, please contact info@opportunityfund.org!

loans.use: Secure a new retail location, increase inventory

loans.name: Yaneris Isolina

texts.es:
la joven Yaneris H. es una mujer ejemplar, digna de imitarla pues se dedica al negocio propio, tiene una 
pulperia desde hace pocos años, Yaneris es madre de un bebe de 12 meses, 
junto con su esposo trabajan duro para sacar a su familia adelante y su hogar. 
la joven Yaneris se levanta a las 5 de la mañana para atender a su clientela ya que vive en una zona 
bien productiva.
Yaneris en sus tiempos libres se  dedica  a cuidar a su hija que es lo que mas quiere en este mundo.
texts.en:
Yaneris is an exemplary young woman, worthy of imitation because she has been running her own grocery store for a few years now. Yaneris is the mother of a baby (12 months of age). She and her husband work hard to get ahead and improve their family and home. Yaneris wakes up each day at 5 am to serve her customers in their busy and productive locale. In her free time, Yaneris spends her time caring for her daughter, whom she loves more than anything else in the world.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: compra de pan, cebollas, tomates, repollos, galletas, refrescos, churros, arroz, frijoles, azucar, harina de maiz y trigo, tortillas, lacteos, pastillas, manteca, aceite, jabones, sopas, pastas, chiles, sardinas, refresco en polvo, sal, condimentos (bread, onions, tomatoes, flour, crackers, cornmeal, lard, cooking oil, sugar, soft drinks, soups, pastas, sardines, salt, condiments, soaps, etc.)

loans.name: Maricruz

texts.es: La señora Maricruz G. S. solicita de un préstamo para poder impermeabilizar su vivienda; por que en las temporadas de lluvias el agua se trasmina y su techo se esta deteriorando. Maricruz teme que si deja este problemita puede que se agrave y tenga que gastar más de lo previsto. La señora trabaja en maquiladora y su esposo desde EUA le envía dinero para que cubra los gastos que se aproximen.
texts.en:
Maricruz G. S. is asking for a loan so that she can make her home waterproof. During the rainy season the water seeps through her roof, which is causing it to deteriorate. Maricruz is worried that if she doesn’t fix it the problem will only get worse, and she will have to pay even more to fix her roof. Maricruz works at an assembly plant and her husband works in the US and sends her money to cover their expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Waterproofing her home

loans.name: Teresa Natividad

texts.es:
Teresa es casada, tiene 4 hijos de los cuales solo una hija esta a su responsabilidad, Teresa junto a su hija y esposo realizan trabajos de artesanía en piedra de Huamanga (alabastro), productos que vende en el mercado artesanal de la ciudad, también vende otra variedad de artesanías que compra de los productores.
Teresa pertenece al Banco Comunal Sonrisa y necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles para la compra de retablos y cerámicas.
Teresa sueña con ampliar su negocio y tener una tienda grande.
texts.en:
Teresa is married and has 4 children, of whom only one daughter is her responsibility. Teresa, her daughter and husband make crafts of alabaster, which they sell in the craft market of the city. She also sells a variety of crafts that she buys from the producers. Teresa belongs to the Sonrisa ["Smile"] Community Bank and she needs a loan of 1000 soles for the purchase of altarpieces and ceramics. Teresa dreams of expanding her business and having a large store.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: for the purchase of altarpieces and ceramics

loans.name: Stella Efua

texts.en: Stella Efua E. A. is married. She has been through junior high school. Stella E. sells underwear at Elmina. Her husband is a fisherman. Stella feeds her family as a way of helping her husband. She wishes to purchase more of her goods for sale with the help of the loan. With the new profits from her expanded business, Stella hopes to save toward building a house.

loans.use: purchase more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more meat, fish, salt, tomatoes, rice, cooking oil etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: The purchase of more spare parts for resale

loans.name: Jovinsol's Group

texts.en:
Jovinsol C. is from the village of Brgy.Bonfal East, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 32 years old. Jovinsol is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jovinsol is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovinsol owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling fish balls and other dimsums to the local community. Jovinsol has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jovinsol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovinsol has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jovinsol is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jovinsol from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

location.town: Brgy. Bonfal East, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Rentsenpurev

texts.en: Rentsenpurev H. is 28 years old and lives with his wife and infant son in the Hovd province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife works in the local factory to supplement their family income. Rentsenpurev operates a used consumer goods trading business in his town. He started his business in April, 2010 after moving to his current town. In a short time, he has made much progress in growing his business. He hopes to grow his business further and purchase more products to sell for a profit. For the future, Rentsenpurev says, "My goal is to buy a house and fence for my family." He is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase more winter clothes for his second hand products trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothes

loans.name: Yves

texts.en:
Yves is 36 years old, married and has two children who are one and three years old. He makes a living by running a shop which he also owns called Camera and Photo Designs. He makes a living by charging customers for the use of cameras and printing equipment. He currently has two employees.

He plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to expand his business by buying more cameras.

loans.use: To expand his business by buying more cameras

loans.name: Ciudad Real Group

texts.es: Rufino Martínez tiene 45 años de edad y vive en el distrito de Santa Anita tiene un hijo de 18 años de edad el cual aun esta a su cuidado y le brinda los pagos para sus estudios, Rufino cada día se dedica al manejo de transporte público hace mas de 12 años y comenzó  a ráiz de que un familiar le propuso comprar una pequeña movilidad a un bajo precio ya que era un vehículo usado. Es así como comienza en este trabajo de chofer de su propio vehículo el cual le a dado muchas satisfacciones económicas y poder sustentar su hogar y darle estudios a su hijo que prontamente entrara  a la universidad, en el futuro le gustaría dejar este trabajo y poner una carnicería. Con el reciente préstamo lo invertirá en pintar su vehículo y pasar unas revisiones técnicas. Como el señor Rufino Martínez cada integrante de esta agrupación tiene una meta a futuro y un gran deseo por salir adelante y poder dar a sus hogares la mejor estabilidad económica posible.
texts.en:
Rufino Martínez is 45 years old and lives in Santa Anita district.  He has an 18 year-old son who is still in his care and he pays for his studies.  Rufino works as a public transport driver every day.  He has been in this work for more than 12 years.  He started his business when a family member suggested he buy a small vehicle which was available at a low price as it was a used vehicle.  This is how he started his work driving his own vehicle.  This business has been very rewarding financially and has enabled him to support his household and educate his son who will soon start university.  In the future, he would like to leave this business and set up a butcher's shop.

Rufino will use this loan to invest in having his vehicle painted and having some technical checks done on it.  Just like Rufino Martínez, each member of this group has a future goal and a great desire to get ahead and provide their households with the best financial stability possible.

loans.use: To have his vehicle painted and to have some technical checks done on it

loans.name: Just Try Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Just Try” group. They are small businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Musu Tailor, who is pictured in the back row on the left.  Musu is thirty-two-years old.  She was born in Solima, in southern Sierra Leone. Musu is currently residing in Makeni with her husband and three children. 

For fifteen years,  Musu has been selling palm oil, rice, cigarette, matches, mints, biscuits, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above mentioned items at wholesale to add to her inventory.

loans.use: To buy palm oil, rice, cigarette, matches, mints, biscuits, etc. at wholesale

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
Damira K. is the leader of this group. She is 35 years old, married, and has two sons and a daughter. Her sons are students and her daughter is of  pre-school age (under seven). 

Damira works as a teacher at a school.  Her husband earns money by breeding livestock animals. By reselling livestock after fattening them, he adds 1500 soms to their family budget. With the money received from this loan, Damira wants to increase their number of livestock. In the future, she will make efforts to build a house for her children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Tsedendamba

texts.en:
Tsedendamba, 41, is married and lives with his wife and three children in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on land that his parents owned for 40 years. His wife is unemployed and his son works at a local police station.

Tsedendamba has been operating his ironsmith business at his home consistently since 1991. Now he is popular in his area and people come to his shop to place orders. In addition to his ironsmith business, he operates a welding service too. His business is the main source of his family's income. Now he is building a house and will use one room as a workshop. Tsedendamba is a hardworking and kind person who says, "Operating the business at home is difficult and I want to have my own workshop." He is requesting a loan of 350,000 MNT to purchase more materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more materials.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mr. Heng B. is 41 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Kong Run, is 40 years old. They live in a village about twenty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have four children - one son and three daughters.   

Mr. Heng B. is a construction worker and farmer. He also raises chickens at home. His wife is a garment factory worker. He is asking for his first loan of $250 to purchase more chickens to raise.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens to raise.

loans.name: C4706 Tuzamuranetwese Group

texts.en:
Chantal is 36 years old and married with two children. She owns a business selling foodstuffs such as sugar, rice, and salt. Chantal is the leader of the group which is called "Tuzamuranetwese" in the local language. This group contains five members: three women and two men. Chantal is in the middle raising her hand.

Chantal and her group have requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand their businesses through purchasing more products such as sugar, bananas, rice and salt. Through this expansion, Chantal will be able to earn more profit which will be used to pay school fees for her children and save for her future.

loans.use: to purchase more goods such as sugar, rice and bananas

loans.name: Junelyn

texts.en:
Junelyn is a mother to 2 young children ages 4 and 9 months. She is 22 years old and married. Junelyn is engaged in farming. She helps her husband, who is a farmer, maintain their rice farm. She helps in keeping the farm free of weeds and pests. Junelyn does her best to help provide for her family. She also takes good care of her children.

Junelyn's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for their harvest to increase.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: This is 24 year-old Mohamed Alieu S..  He is married, and has 1 7 year old child aged. In 2008, Mohamed Alieu S. established his essential drugs business. He began his business because he wants to generate income and support his child.  Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,000,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000. Mohamed requires a loan in order to buy more essential drugs stock for business. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Mohamed plans to educate his child, establish savings and hire workers to run the shop. He is very serious and dedicated.  He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more essential drugs for his pharmacy

loans.name: Nigar

texts.en:
Nigar K., age 42, is engaged in vegetable farming, a traditional occupation for many people living in the southern part of Azerbaijan. She and her husband have two children. She chose to enter this kind of work because neither she nor her husband have been able to find steady employment, so they decided to make use of the fairly large amount of land surrounding their house. In this way, they manage to support the family. 

Nigar has garnered a good amount of experience growing and selling produce, and she wants to grow more vegebles so as to generate more income for her family. She is requesting a loan to buy mineral fertilizer and seeds so she can expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: El señor Carlos tiene un sistema de amplificación con el que ofrece servicios de D.J. en recepciones sociales. El crédito lo requiere para comprar un equipo de mayor poder amplificador, así podrá  aumentar su capital de trabajo y ofrecer mejor servicio a sus clientes. Vive en alquiler en una casa ubicada en la zona de Miraflores de la ciudad de La Paz;  es separado  y tiene cinco hijos. Es la primera vez que obtiene un crédito con IMPRO.
texts.en: Carlos provides DJ services with his amplification equipment at social events and receptions.  He needs a loan to buy a more powerful amplifier.  In this way he can increase his working capital and offer better service to his customers.  He lives in a rented home located in the Miraflores neighborhood of the city of La Paz.  He is separated and has 5 children.  This is the first time he has taken a loan from IMPRO.

loans.use: to buy a more powerful amplifier for his DJ business

loans.name: Kondoa Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth is in her early 30s, single, and has two children, both of whom attend school. She has been a food vendor for 10 years. She works form 6.00 pm to 11.00 pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Elizabeth's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase her food stock and for household expenses and has repaid all her loans successfully.  She is requesting a new loan to increase her food stock. Her dream is to one day buy some land.

Elizabeth will share this loan with her loan group, "Kondoa," which has 15 members who hold each other accountable in repaying the loan.

loans.use: To increase her food stock.

loans.name: Mayra Soledad

texts.es:
La Señorita. Mayra es socia del banco comunal Renacientes, vive por el sector del Vergel en la ciudad de Cuenca, a esta ciudad le hace hermosa su gente, su cultura, tradiciones, la belleza de su naturaleza y arquitectura, también es conocida como cuna de grandes deportistas, tiene una variada  gastronomía que cautiva a propios y extraños.
 
La Señorita. Mayra es soltera tiene 20 años de edad, vive en casa de sus padres a quienes les ayuda con  los gastos del hogar, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.

Nuestra socia labora como empleada domestica, trabaja de lunes a viernes solo medio día y el resto de su tiempo lo dedica a trabajar en el negocio familiar que es la fabricación artículos de hierro forjado.
 
Se encuentra en su segundo crédito que realiza en el banco comunal y su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de de materia prima como hierro, sueldas, pinturas, etc. para la fabricación de artículos en  hierro forjado.
 
Su meta es  tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Srta. Mayra is a member of the Communal Bank “Renacientes” (The Resurgents). She lives in the Vergel sector of the city of Cuenca. This city is beautiful because of its people, its culture, its tradition, its natural settings, and its architecture. It is also the birthplace of great athletes and has a variety of cuisines that captivates the palates of locals and foreigners.

Srta. Mayra is 20 years old and single. She lives at home with her parents and helps them with the household expenses. They live in a rental property since they do not own a home.

Mayra works as a housekeeper Monday through Friday, but only for half a day. She spends the rest of the time working at the family business which manufactures products made of forged iron.

Mayra is requesting her second loan from the Communal Bank. She will invest the funds in the purchase of raw materials such as iron, welding equipment, paints, and other items for making forged iron products. Her goal is to have a house of her own.

loans.use: to purchase iron, welding equipment, paints, and other items.

loans.name: Victoire Pétrina

texts.fr:
Victoire Petrina est une femme âgée de 46 ans. Elle est veuve avec un enfant.
Victorie Petrina a travaillé comme revendeuse depuis 2000. Elle vend des habits et chaussures de friperie au marché du Sanguera. Elle achète les produits au marché de Hédzranawoé.
Victorie Petrina a requis son troisième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter 2 balles d'habits de friperie et 6 douzaine de pairs de chaussures.
texts.en:
Victoire Petrina is a 46 years old woman. She is a widow with one child.
Victorie Petrina has been working as a retailer since 2000. She sells second-hand clothing and shoes at the market in Sanguera. She purchases products from the Hédzranawoé market.
Victorie Petrina requested her third loan from WAGES to purchase two bundles of second-hand clothing and six dozen pairs of shoes.

loans.use: to buy clothing bundles.

loans.name: Binti

texts.en:
Binti is a married woman with 7 children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of establishing a food stall in the future.

With the 10,000 KES, she wants to purchase bundles of mangoes, cassavas and green vegetables. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of mangoes, cassavas and green vegetables

loans.name: Mogina

texts.en:
Mogina is 51 years old and is a married woman with 6 children. Her eldest child is 25 years old, and the youngest is 9. 

She is a farmer. She and her husband own and till land in Veruela, Agusan Del Sur. Rice is the main crop that they grow and sell. She does her best to support her family and send her children to school.

She has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers and fuel for the tractor. Mogina is hopeful that this loan will help them achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and fuel for the tractor.

loans.name: Mabomba Mengi Group

texts.en:
Balozi, who is in his early forties, is married with three children, two of whom go to school. He has had a tailoring business since 1988. He works from 8am to 6pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit. 

This will be his fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to buy sewing materials and household expenses and has paid back all his loans successfully. He hopes for a loan to buy an overlocking machine. His dream is to own more sewing machines so that he can win big government tenders.

He will share this loan with his loan group, "Mabomba Mengi", which has a total of 18 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy an overlocking machine.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity is 23 years old and married woman with one child. Her child is still too young for school. She has a business selling drugs in a clinic in Jigomoni Branch in Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.

Charity requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase more drugs to sell in her clinic

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is 42 years old and the wife of a farmer. She owns a small variety store in their community where she sells soft drinks, milk, breads and rice. She is earning PHP 3,000 every month which is usually used for daily expenses.

She is requesting a loan amount of PHP 6,000 to buy butter, candies, salt, soy sauce and vinegar as additional goods for her store. She hopes this will help her business to progress in terms of earning a higher profit for the education of her three children.

loans.use: to buy butter, candies, salt, soy sauce and vinegar as additional goods for her store.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda spends most of her time in raising pigs. She had been married for almost eight years but not yet been blessed with a child. The couple are praying to have a child too. Through hog raising, Rosalinda was able to earn a profit of PHP 1,000 for each hog she was able to sell to the butchers who came to their village.
